Requirements:
To be accepted into the Master of Accountancy program, an applicant should have the academic potential and the motivation to successfully complete a graduate degree in accountancy. Typically, applicants will have an undergraduate degree in accounting from an AACSB-accredited business school and a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher.

Required application materials:

- Graduate School application and fee
- A resume or curriculum vita
- A one-page statement of objectives for pursuing graduate study
- Official transcripts from each college or university attended. A minimum grade point average of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale for the last 60 hours of coursework is required.
- Three letters of recommendation. You will be asked to provide names and email addresses for your references in the application. An email will be sent to your references with instructions for submitting their letter.
- Official GMAT scores. An official report of your scores on the Graduate Management Admission Test must be submitted. The GMAT may be waived for graduates of the K-State accounting program who meet specific academic criteria. Contact the MAcc program director for details.
- For non-native English speakers, an official report of TOEFL, IELTS or PTE scores.

A one- to two-page statement of goals/objective for undertaking graduate study should address your professional goals and the contributions you will make to the nursing profession. A current resume or curriculum vitae. Three professional references from a current or recent employer/supervisor, a former nursing faculty member or other healthcare professional who can speak to your professional and academic potential. References should be from individuals who have a master's or doctoral degree. Official transcripts from each institution attended. Proof of unencumbered RN licensure in the state where clinicals will be completed. Evidence of completion of both a graduate-level (500 level or higher) pathophysiology and pharmacology course with a grade of B or better from an accredited university. Verification of a minimum of one year of full-time work experience (or its part-time equivalent) as a RN in a critical care setting. A letter from a current or past employer on letterhead is required. Copy of current Advanced Cardiac Life Support (ACLS) certification. Copy of current Basic Life Support (BLS) certification. Copy of current Critical Care Registered Nurse (CCRN) certification. Preferred, but not required.
Program name: Adult-Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner Cert

Requirements:
GPA of 3.0 or higher on a 4.0 scale for the Bachelor of Science in Nursing degree.
A current unencumbered Kansas Registered Nurse (RN) license. If you are a resident of a state other than Kansas, you must have a current unencumbered RN license from your state of residence.
A Bachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN) from a CCNE, ACEN, or CNEA accredited nursing program.
Two years of full-time direct patient care experience as an RN in a critical care setting within the last five years. Critical care experience is defined as direct patient care in an adult critical care unit, such as a medical, surgical, trauma or coronary care unit. Experience in neonatal ICU, pediatric ICU, emergency department, operating room and post-anesthesia care unit (PACU) is not sufficient.
Current advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) and basic life support (BLS) provider certification.
Completion of a three-credit-hour undergraduate or graduate statistics course with a grade of B or better.
Completion of the K-State Graduate School application.
Three professional letters of recommendation.
Submission of all official transcripts from any college/university attended.
Submission of professional curriculum vitae (CV) or resume.
Submission of a two- to three-page, double-spaced personal statement addressing specific questions.
Completion of a successful interview.
Program name: Adult-Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner MSN

Requirements:
Admission requirements: Must have a BSN and a graduate degree from an accredited institution. Must hold an active RN license to practice in Kansas. A cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher is required.

Application checklist:
- A curriculum vitae (CV) or resume.
- A one- to two-page statement of goals/objectives.
- One official transcript from each post-secondary institution attended. Official transcripts must be sent directly from the granting institution to Kansas State University.
- Copy of your Kansas Registered Nurse License.
- The GRE is not required for admission to this certificate program.
- Three professional references (names and contact information).
Program name: Adult-Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner Cert

Requirements:
The applicant must have graduated from an ACEN or CCNE accredited baccalaureate degree program in nursing. Admission to the graduate program in nursing is granted to those who show high promise of success. Admission is competitive and based upon the following:

1. A completed online Graduate School application.
2. A statement of objectives that addresses how the M.S.N. degree will assist the applicant in meeting career goals. The Statement of Objectives should be limited to 500 words and uploaded with the application.
3. Official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended must be submitted to the Graduate School.
4. A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale.
5. A current unencumbered license as a registered professional nurse in the U.S. A Kansas license must be obtained prior to beginning any clinical experience.
6. A minimum of one year of full-time work experience as a registered nurse is preferred.
7. A professional resume or curriculum vitae that is uploaded with the application.
8. Three professional references who can attest to the applicant’s potential for success in a graduate program. One reference should be from a current employer. References will be asked to complete a recommendation form within the online application.
9. International applicants from non-English speaking countries must meet the minimum English proficiency requirements for full admission.
10. An undergraduate course in statistics with a grade of C or better. Completion of statistics coursework with a grade of C or better within the last 5 years is preferred.
11. An interview with the nursing graduate admission committee may be requested.
12. A completed background check is required for all admitted students.
Program name: Adult-Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner MSN

Requirements: The following application materials are required: an online application form and fee through the Graduate School, transcripts from all previous institutions attended, three letters of recommendation, a 1-2 page personal statement explaining why you want to earn a graduate degree in mass communications and why you believe you will be successful in our graduate program, a current professional resume, and a writing sample that best represents your writing skills. GRE scores are not required for admission to the master's program. For international applicants, TOEFL or IELTS scores are required if your native language is not English.

A grade point average of 3.0 or higher in the last 60 hours of coursework. At least 15 hours in anthropology with a minimum GPA of 3.2, including one course in each of the three subdisciplines (sociocultural, biological, archaeology). Three letters of recommendation from former professors or others able to judge the student’s academic potential. A statement of intent describing why the applicant wants to pursue an M.A. in anthropology at Kansas State University and how our program fits their interests. Official transcripts from all universities and/or colleges attended. A completed Graduate School Application Form. An application fee.

The following items must be submitted through the K-State Graduate School online application: Unofficial transcripts from all colleges and universities attended; Three letters of recommendation; A statement of purpose; A current résumé or curriculum vitae (CV); A writing sample. International students whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency.

Students not currently enrolled in a graduate degree program at K-State must apply for admission to the Graduate School as a non-degree student seeking a graduate certificate. The following materials should be submitted through the K-State Graduate School online application:
1. A brief (1-2 pages) statement describing your background and why you are interested in this certificate program.
2. A resume or curriculum vitae.
3. Official transcripts from all post-secondary institutions attended.

1. A graduate degree (master’s or specialist) from a regionally accredited institution. Students with a specialist degree will be given preference for transfer hours.
2. A 3.25 graduate GPA.
3. Statement of goals and objectives: Submit a 3-5 page paper detailing your background, professional goals and objectives, and how this Ed.D. program will help you meet those goals. In addition, please describe any research background you have and a potential research focus of interest to you as a doctoral student.
4. A writing sample that demonstrates your scholarly writing ability.
5. Three professional references.
6. A current resume or vita.
7. Successful interview with program faculty.

Earned master’s degree from an accredited institution with a GPA of 3.25 or higher
Minimum of three years of professional experience
Kansas State University Graduate School application
Official transcripts from each institution attended
Graduate Record Examination (GRE) scores are not required
Three letters of reference from individuals who can attest to your ability to be successful in a doctoral program
Curriculum vitae or resume
Letter of intent: The letter of intent should include your professional background and goals, areas of interest and how your interests align with program faculty.
Writing sample: The writing sample should demonstrate your potential to write critically and scholarly in a field of study.

An undergraduate degree with a grade point average (GPA) of 3.0 or higher in the last 60 hours of coursework. Statement of goals and objectives that addresses why you are interested in the program, and what your career goals are. Three letters of recommendation. You will be asked for the names and email addresses of three references. The online system will contact them and provide them with a link to upload their letters. Resume/curriculum vitae (CV). The GRE is not required. Transcripts from all colleges and universities attended.

A bachelor’s degree from an accredited institution with a minimum GPA of 3.0 in the last 60 hours of undergraduate coursework.
Applicants should have taken at least 15 hours of coursework in geography, remote sensing, or a related field.
Proficiency in the English language. All applicants are required to meet the English proficiency requirements set by the K-State Graduate School.
One-page statement of purpose that describes background, career goals, and how the Applied Remote Sensing MPS degree will help reach those goals.
Three letters of recommendation from individuals familiar with applicant’s academic or professional abilities.
Resume.

Application for admission must include:
- A one-page statement of objectives.
- Three letters of recommendation from former professors or professional associates.
- A one-page curriculum vita/resume.
- A portfolio of academic and/or professional work is optional for those with a professional architectural engineering or architecture degree from an EAC/ABET or NAAB accredited program; a portfolio is required for all other applicants.

Applicants for admission to the MSAE program must present a Bachelor of Science degree in architectural engineering or a closely related engineering or architecture field, with a GPA of 3.0 or higher in the last 60 hours of coursework.

International students must meet the English proficiency requirements.

Admission to this program requires a bachelor's degree with a 3.0 GPA on the last 60 hours of coursework. Required application materials include the Graduate School application and fee, and official transcripts. International applicants must also submit proof of English language proficiency.

To be admitted to the certificate program, a student must be a high school graduate or equivalent and be admitted to Kansas State University as either a degree-seeking or non-degree seeking student. The student must have the background to succeed in introductory music courses at the 100 level and have a sufficient music background to succeed in one applied area (instrument or voice). Admission to the certificate program requires an audition in an applied area. Auditions are conducted by the appropriate applied area faculty.

To be admitted to the program, students must have a baccalaureate degree from an accredited institution with a GPA of 3.0 or higher.

Application materials:

1. A graduate school application.
2. Official transcripts from each institution attended.
3. Statement of purpose.
4. Resume or curriculum vitae.
5. Three letters of recommendation.

To apply for the online arts management graduate certificate, you must have:

* a bachelor's degree with a minimum 3.0 GPA in the last 60 hours of coursework
* submitted the K-State Graduate School application
* submitted official transcripts from each college or university attended
* an updated resume or curriculum vitae
* a one-page statement of purpose explaining your interest in the program
Students must apply and be admitted to Kansas State University to earn the certificate.

To be considered for admission into the Master of Science in Athletic Training (MSAT) program, prospective students must complete both the Athletic Training Centralized Application Service (ATCAS) application and the K-State Graduate School application.

Application Requirements:
1. Complete the ATCAS application (atcas.liaisoncas.com).
2. Complete the K-State Graduate School application (k-state.edu/grad/application).
3. Possess or be on-track to earn a Bachelor's degree from a regionally accredited institution.
4. Have an overall cumulative undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher on a 4.0 scale.
5. Complete the specified prerequisite coursework from a regionally accredited institution with a prerequisite GPA of 3.0 or higher and a grade of C or better in all prerequisite courses.
6. Provide three (3) letters of recommendation from individuals that can attest to the applicant's academic and clinical abilities. At least one letter must be from a certified athletic trainer. Letters should be submitted through ATCAS.
7. Provide a one-page, single-spaced personal statement describing the applicant's desire to become an athletic trainer. The statement should be submitted through ATCAS.
8. Provide an up-to-date resume/CV that highlights relevant experience. The resume/CV should be submitted through ATCAS.
9. Complete and submit proof of a minimum of 50 hours of observation of athletic training clinical practice under the direct supervision of a certified athletic trainer. Observation hours should be submitted through ATCAS.
10. Submit official transcripts from all colleges/universities attended. Transcripts should be submitted through ATCAS.
11. Complete an on-campus or virtual interview with the MSAT admissions committee (by invitation only).
12. Meet the Technical Standards for Admission.

The student must have a bachelor's degree in a related field, such as atmospheric science, meteorology, chemistry, computer science, engineering, physics, mathematics or other physical science. Minimum academic requirements are a 3.0 grade point average on a 4.0 scale in the last two years of undergraduate study. Official transcripts, three letters of recommendation, statement of objectives and a resume/CV must be submitted.

The following materials must be uploaded with your online application:

- Application form
- Application fee
- Official transcripts from each college or university attended. Your GPA should be 3.0 or higher on a 4.0 scale for the last 60 hours of coursework.
- Three letters of recommendation. Your recommenders will receive an e-mail with a link to upload their letters of recommendation directly to your application file.
- Statement of purpose/objectives (1-2 pages).
- Curriculum Vitae (CV) / Resume.
- For international students: TOEFL, PTE, or IELTS scores are required if English is not your native language. A financial statement is also required.

A minimum GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale.
Letters of recommendation (3)
Statement of purpose/objectives
Prerequisite coursework:
Mathematics through ordinary differential equations (e.g., MATH 340)
Physics through general physics (e.g., PHYS 213, PHYS 214)
One course in chemistry (e.g., CHM 210)
One course in statistics (e.g., STAT 340)

Applications are made online through the K-State Graduate School. You will need to complete all parts of the application process.
1. Complete the online application.
2. Pay the application fee.
3. Upload unofficial transcripts from each college or university attended. Unofficial transcripts should include the student’s name, the institution’s name, and all grades received, including the grade key. Official transcripts will be required upon admission.
4. Upload a statement of objectives. The statement should address your reasons for seeking a graduate degree in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, your research interests, and your career goals.
5. Provide contact information for three references. The reference providers will be contacted automatically and asked to upload a letter of recommendation. It is important to ask potential references before listing them.
6. Upload a resume/CV (optional).
7. Upload official TOEFL, IELTS, or PTE scores (if applicable). Use K-State’s institution code 6334.

The following requirements for admission are in addition to the general requirements for admission to the Graduate School at Kansas State University.

A one-page statement of the applicant’s research experience, research interests, and professional objectives.
GRE general test scores are required for all applicants. There is no minimum GRE score for admission.
Three letters of recommendation are required from faculty or others who are able to assess the applicant’s potential for graduate study. At least one letter should be from an individual who supervised the applicant in a research setting, if possible.
For applicants whose native language is not English, a score of at least 550 (paper-based), 213 (computer-based), or 79 (internet-based) on the TOEFL, 6.5 on the IELTS, or 58 on the PTE is required.

Applicants should have a master's degree in a STEM field and have five years of professional experience in an academic, government or industry laboratory. Applications are accepted on a rolling basis.
Program name: Biochemistry and Molecular Biology Executive PhD Online

Requirements: A bachelor's degree from an accredited institution with a GPA of 3.0 or higher. For admission into the master's program, we expect students to have completed two semesters of general chemistry, two semesters of organic chemistry, two semesters of physics and one semester of calculus. Applicants are required to identify and contact potential faculty mentors to ensure a good fit in the program and availability of the mentor.

The following materials are required for an application to be complete and reviewed by our graduate admissions committee. All materials must be submitted via the online application system of the K-State Graduate School.
- A completed application form and application fee
- Transcripts from all colleges and universities attended
- A statement of purpose (1-2 pages) describing your reasons for seeking a graduate degree in Biology at K-State, your specific research interests, your career goals, and any other information you think is relevant to your application. A strong statement will demonstrate that you have clear ideas about what you want to study in graduate school and that our program is a good fit for those interests. In your statement, you must identify at least three faculty members in the Division of Biology with whom you would like to work and explain why.
- Three letters of recommendation
- Curriculum vitae (CV)
- International applicants must also provide proof of English proficiency

All applicants must meet Graduate School requirements. Additional admission requirements are as follows:
1. A bachelor’s degree in engineering from an ABET-accredited program with a GPA of 3.0 or higher in the last 60 hours of coursework. Students with degrees in related fields such as biology, chemistry, physics, and mathematics may be admitted with the understanding they will need to complete specified undergraduate engineering coursework. Applicants with a GPA below 3.0 may be considered for provisional admission on a case-by-case basis.
2. Three letters of recommendation.
3. Official transcripts from all post-secondary institutions attended.
4. A one-page statement of purpose describing the applicant’s academic and career goals, research interests, and qualifications for graduate study in biomedical engineering.
5. A resume/CV outlining education, work experience, publications, honors, and other pertinent information.
6. For international students, a TOEFL, IELTS, or PTE score that meets the minimum university requirement.
For Fall 2024 admission, GRE scores are not required.

Applicants for admission must have a bachelor of science degree in engineering or in a physical or biological science with a GPA of 3.0 or higher. For students with a BS degree in an area other than engineering, leveling courses may be required. Application is through the Graduate School. GRE is not required.

Admission is a two-step process. In the first step, the BME admissions committee reviews the applicant’s package, including transcripts, statement of purpose and letters of recommendation. Those applicants who are found to be qualified will be notified by the BME program director. In the second step, the applicant must find a BME faculty member who is willing to serve as a major professor. A list of faculty and their research interests will be provided to the qualified applicants. The applicant is encouraged to communicate directly with those faculty who are working in the same area of interest.

Formal acceptance will follow when a faculty member has agreed to serve as major professor for the applicant.

Students applying to the M.S. program should possess a B.S. degree in a quantitative scientific field, preferably in engineering or physics, from an ABET-accredited program, with a GPA of 3.0 or higher in the last two years of undergraduate study. GRE scores are not required. The general requirements for admission to graduate study at Kansas State University must also be satisfied.

All applicants must submit an online application that includes the following: a statement of objectives, three letters of reference, and an application fee. Applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency.
Program name: Biomedical Engineering MSBE with emphasis in Medical Physics

Requirements: Applicants must have a bachelor's degree in engineering or the physical sciences from an ABET-accredited program, with a minimum 3.0 GPA. A minimum GRE score of 155 on the quantitative section is required. For non-native English speakers, a minimum TOEFL score of 550 (paper), 213 (computer), or 79 (iBT) is required, or a minimum IELTS score of 6.5. Applicants should identify a graduate faculty member with whom they have a common research interest and a willingness to be a major advisor. Application materials must include a statement of objectives, three letters of recommendation, and transcripts from all previous institutions. Applications must be submitted through the K-State Graduate School.
Program name: Biomedical Engineering PhD with emphasis in Medical Physics

Requirements:
A D.V.M. (or equivalent international degree) or a B.S. or B.A. degree from an accredited institution. A minimum 3.0 G.P.A. on a 4.0 scale during the last two years of the B.S./B.A. curriculum is required for provisional admission to the master’s program.

Application materials to be uploaded:

- Transcripts from all previous coursework.
- Statement of Objectives
- Current Resume or Vita
- Names and e-mail addresses for three professional references
- International Students: English Language Proficiency minimum requirements must be met.

A bachelor’s degree from an accredited institution. An undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher (on a 4.0 scale). The Graduate Record Examination (GRE) general test is not required for admission. Three letters of recommendation. At least two letters should be from faculty at previous institutions who can comment on your academic and research potential. A Statement of Objectives outlining your career goals, research interests, and relevant experiences. A resume/CV detailing your education, research experience, publications, awards, and work history. International students whose native language is not English are required to take the TOEFL exam and must meet the minimum requirements as set by the K-State Graduate School.

Admission to the M.S. program is based on the student's academic record, letters of reference, and statement of objectives. Students are expected to have completed a calculus sequence and a course in linear algebra. Applicants are strongly encouraged to have had at least one course in mathematical statistics. The Graduate School requires that students have a 3.0 GPA in their last 60 hours of course work. The GRE is not required for admission. The following materials should be submitted as part of your online application: Graduate School application form, Transcripts from all post-secondary institutions attended, Three letters of recommendation, A statement of objectives, A list of all college-level mathematics and statistics courses taken.

Application to the PhD program requires the following:

A bachelor's degree.
At least a 3.0 GPA in the last 60 hours of undergraduate coursework.
Three letters of reference.
A statement of objectives.
Graduate Record Examination (GRE) scores are optional for applicants.
Non-native English speakers should demonstrate their English proficiency through one of the following tests: TOEFL, IELTS, or PTE.

Required application materials: 1. Graduate School application form; 2. Official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended from which you have a degree or have more than 15 credit hours; 3. Statement of objectives: A one- to two-page statement of your academic objectives; 4. Three letters of reference from people who can provide a frank and objective assessment of your academic and/or professional abilities and your potential as a graduate student; 5. Resume or curriculum vitae.

For admission to the Business Certificate, you must hold a bachelor’s degree from an accredited institution. Applicants must meet the admission requirements of the Graduate School to be admitted into a certificate program. The application process is handled through the Graduate School. A minimum GPA of 3.0 in the last 60 hours of undergraduate coursework is required for full admission.

Admission to the DBA is a two-step process. First, applicants are evaluated on a portfolio that includes a series of personal interviews, an online application form, a summary of professional experience (resume), and two professional references from supervisors. Qualified applicants who are offered admission to the DBA program will then apply to the Graduate School. Admission to the DBA program does not guarantee admission to the Graduate School. Applicants must hold a graduate degree in a business or business-related field (e.g., MBA, MAcc, MS, JD, etc.) from an accredited institution. Consideration will be given to candidates with degrees from other disciplines on a case-by-case basis. Applicants must have at least ten years of progressive managerial experience, including five years of senior-level management and/or consulting experience. Competitive applicants will be highly motivated, mature business executives who have a high level of intellectual curiosity and a desire to contribute to applied business research.

The requirements for admission to the Business Administration doctoral program are as follows:

1. A master’s degree from an accredited institution. Students with a strong undergraduate degree but no master’s degree may be admitted provisionally and must complete the requirements of one of the College of Business Administration master’s programs during the first year of study.
2. A grade point average (GPA) of 3.25 or higher on a 4.0 scale on all previous graduate work.
3. A score on the Graduate Management Admission Test (GMAT) or Graduate Record Examination (GRE) taken within the last five years. GMAT scores are preferred.
4. Letters of recommendation from three individuals familiar with the applicant’s academic background and potential.
5. A personal statement from the applicant setting forth career goals and objectives.
6. International applicants must demonstrate English proficiency.

The required components of the application package are detailed below. All materials must be submitted through the Graduate School's online application portal.
1. Graduate School Application
2. Transcripts
3. GMAT or GRE Score
4. Letters of Recommendation
5. Statement of Purpose
6. Resume or CV
7. TOEFL / IELTS / PTE Score (International Students)
8. Financial Affidavit (International Students)

Applicants must have an MBA or master’s degree in a business-related field. Students who are admitted without a recent MBA may be required to take additional course work to demonstrate proficiency in the core business areas.

In addition to the requirements of the Graduate School, applicants for the PhD in business administration must submit the following materials:

- Graduate Management Admissions Test (GMAT) or Graduate Record Examination (GRE) scores. GMAT scores are preferred.
- TOEFL scores (for international students only).
- three letters of recommendation.
- a statement of objectives.
- a resume.
- transcripts.

An earned undergraduate degree from a regionally accredited U.S. institution or a degree from a non-U.S. institution of higher education that is judged equivalent to a U.S. bachelor's degree by the Graduate School.

A cumulative undergraduate GPA of 3.250 on a 4.0 scale.

An earned Bachelor of Science in Business Administration degree from Kansas State University in one of the following majors: accounting, business administration, entrepreneurship, finance, management, management information systems or marketing.

For the GMAT/GRE requirement, one of the following must be met:

An overall GMAT score of 500 or higher
A combined verbal and quantitative GRE score of 300 or higher
The student must have passed all three parts of the CPA exam on their first attempt.
The student must have passed the Fundamentals of Engineering exam.
The student must have five or more years of continuous professional work experience with evidence of managerial/supervisory responsibilities.
Two letters of recommendation.

Statement of goals and objectives. This should be a one- to two-page essay, double-spaced and typed, that clearly articulates the applicant's reasons for seeking the MBA degree, as well as their short- and long-term professional goals.

A current resume.

To be admitted to the Accelerated MBA in Real Estate program, a student must be an enrolled Kansas State University undergraduate student or have been admitted into an undergraduate degree program at Kansas State University.

Students may apply for admission into the Accelerated MBA in Real Estate program during their junior year (or after completion of 75 undergraduate credit hours). Applicants must have a minimum 3.25 Kansas State University cumulative GPA.

To apply, students will submit the following through the Kansas State University Graduate School online application:

*   Three letters of recommendation
*   Current resume
*   Statement of purpose (one to two pages, double-spaced) addressing the following:
    *   How personal, academic and/or work experiences have shaped your interest in the MBA program
    *   Your career goals upon graduation
*   GMAT/GRE is not required
Program name: Business Administration Accelerated MBA in Real Estate
Business Administration Executive MBA in Health Management and Policy

Requirements:
To apply to the K-State MBA program, you must complete the K-State Graduate School application and submit the following documents. All application materials should be submitted electronically with the online application.
1. Graduate School Application
2. Official transcripts
3. Three letters of recommendation
4. Statement of purpose
5. Resume
6. GMAT or GRE test score (GMAT/GRE scores are currently being waived)
7. English proficiency test score (if applicable)

An undergraduate degree in a quantitative discipline such as business, engineering, computer science, economics, statistics or a similar field with an undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher. Resume. Statement of purpose. Three letters of recommendation. Official transcripts. GMAT or GRE scores (may be waived for exceptional applicants). For international students, a minimum TOEFL (IBT) score of 79, a minimum IELTS score of 6.5, or a minimum PTE score of 58.

A bachelor’s degree from an accredited institution.
An undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher in the last 60 hours of coursework.
A current resume.
Three professional letters of reference.
A statement of objectives.
Official transcripts.
An on-campus or telephone interview with the PMT program director.
International students may have additional requirements.
A GRE is not required.

Admission to the doctoral program requires that the student has completed a master's degree or its equivalent in economics or a related field, such as agricultural economics. Students also may be admitted after completion of a bachelor's degree. Students entering with a bachelor's degree will be required to earn a master's degree in economics at K-State as a normal part of their PhD program.
Students seeking admission to the PhD program must submit:
1. Graduate School application form.
2. Transcripts from all colleges and universities attended. An undergraduate GPA of at least 3.0 on a 4.0 scale is required for admission into the master's program. In most cases, a graduate GPA of at least 3.0 on a 4.0 scale is required for admission to the PhD program.
3. Three letters of recommendation.
4. A one-page statement of objectives.
5. A curriculum vitae (CV).
6. The Graduate Record Examination (GRE) is required. The analytical writing section of the GRE is not required.
7. For non-native English speakers, an English proficiency test is required (e.g., TOEFL, IELTS, PTE). Students must score at least 79 on the TOEFL iBT, 6.5 on the IELTS, or 58 on the PTE.

An applicant must have a bachelor’s degree in electrical engineering or computer engineering from an ABET-accredited program, or a related field. An applicant must have a cumulative undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher on a 4.0 scale. International students must satisfy the Graduate School’s English proficiency requirements. All applicants must submit the following materials: Graduate School online application. Official transcripts for all previous college coursework. Three letters of reference from persons in a position to assess the applicant’s potential for success in a graduate program. A statement of objectives stating the applicant’s interests and goals. A resume. The GRE is not required.

The following are the minimum requirements for admission to graduate study in electrical and computer engineering at K-State.

1. A bachelor of science degree in electrical engineering, computer engineering, or a closely related field, from an ABET-accredited engineering curriculum or the equivalent.
2. A junior-senior grade point average of 3.0 or higher on a 4.0 scale.
3. If the applicant’s native language is not English, the applicant must demonstrate English proficiency. See the Graduate School website for more information.
4. Graduate Record Examination (GRE) scores are not required. GRE scores will not be considered in the admission decision.

A bachelor of science degree in electrical engineering, computer engineering, computer science, or a closely related field from an ABET-accredited institution or a recognized international university. A grade point average of 3.0 or higher on a 4.0 scale in the last 60 hours of undergraduate coursework. The GRE is not required. International students from non-English speaking countries must meet the minimum English proficiency requirements set by the Graduate School. The department may grant provisional admission to an applicant who does not meet all of the above requirements. An online application is required along with a statement of objectives, three letters of reference, transcripts from all institutions attended, and an application fee.
Program name: Electrical and Computer Engineering MSECE with emphasis in Artificial Intelligence

Requirements: A bachelor of science degree in electrical engineering, computer engineering, computer science, or a closely related discipline from an ABET-accredited institution or a recognized international institution. A minimum grade point average (GPA) of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale for the last two years of the bachelor’s degree. Three letters of recommendation submitted directly by the references. A statement of objectives that is consistent with the research focus areas of the ECE graduate faculty. A resume is required. For non-native English speakers, an official report of the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL), International English Language Testing System (IELTS), or Pearson Test of English (PTE) is required. Graduate Record Examination (GRE) scores are optional.
Program name: Electrical and Computer Engineering MSECE with emphasis in Cybersecurity

Requirements:
Applicants to the PhD in English program should have completed a master’s degree in English or a closely related field. Applicants should have a minimum graduate GPA of 3.5. Applications are considered for fall admission only and must be completed by January 8. To apply, students must complete the online application for admission to the graduate school at K-State and submit the following supplemental materials:

*   A statement of purpose (approximately 500-750 words) that describes your primary interests in literary, cultural, or rhetorical studies; your relevant experience as a student, teacher, or scholar; and your professional goals.
*   A curriculum vitae.
*   A writing sample of 15-20 pages that demonstrates your ability to conduct original research and produce sophisticated, polished academic prose.
*   Three letters of recommendation from former professors who can speak to your academic strengths and your promise as a scholar and teacher.
*   Transcripts from all previous post-secondary institutions.

Applicants must have a BS or BA degree in science, engineering, or other appropriate discipline from an accredited institution. A GPA of 3.0 or higher for the last 60 hours of undergraduate coursework is also required. A TOEFL score of 575 (paper), 232 (computer), or 89 (internet) is required for international students whose native language is not English. Applications must be submitted online. Applicants must provide a resume, an official transcript from each college or university attended, a statement of objectives, and three professional references.

Admission to the Environmental Science and Policy graduate program requires a bachelor's or master's degree from an accredited institution and a minimum 3.0 grade point average on a 4.0 scale during the last 60 hours of coursework. Applications are submitted through the Graduate School online application system. The following materials must be included with your application: Resume or curriculum vitae, Statement of purpose, Unofficial transcripts from each college or university attended, Three letters of reference, English proficiency test scores (if applicable), Application fee.

Applicants to the Epidemiology PhD Program should submit an application to the Graduate School. In addition, to be considered for admission, prospective students must have:
1. A master of public health (MPH) degree or other relevant master’s degree from an accredited university.
2. A grade point average (GPA) of 3.0 or higher in graduate course work.
3. A minimum score of 153 on the quantitative section and 150 on the verbal section on the Graduate Record Exam (GRE). Note that GRE scores are optional for Fall 2024 admissions. A GRE analytical writing score of 4.0 or higher is also recommended.

Other information required as part of the application includes:
1. Three letters of recommendation from former instructors or supervisors who can speak to the applicant’s academic and/or professional capabilities.
2. A statement of objectives explaining why the applicant is seeking a PhD in epidemiology and public health, and how the degree will help him/her to achieve career goals.
3. A current curriculum vitae or resume.
4. Official transcripts from all previously attended colleges and universities.

The application deadline for admission with funding is December 1. The deadline for admission without funding is February 1. To be considered for admission, applicants must meet the following criteria: A master's degree in a relevant area. GPA of 3.0 or higher in master's degree work. Identify a faculty member as a potential mentor. Required Application Materials: Graduate School online application, Graduate School application fee, One official transcript from each college or university attended, Three letters of reference, A curriculum vitae (CV), A statement of objectives, Official TOEFL, PTE, or IELTS scores (for non-native English speakers).

Admission to the Master of Arts in Philosophy program requires a BA or BS degree from an accredited institution. Applicants are expected to have a good liberal arts background. Students who have not had at least 15 hours of philosophy courses may be admitted provisionally and required to make up any deficiencies without credit toward the graduate degree. An undergraduate GPA of at least 3.0 (on a 4.0 scale) in the last 60 hours is required. Students whose native language is not English must provide a TOEFL score of at least 550 (213 on the computer-based test, 79 on the Internet-based test). For details on this requirement, consult the Graduate School website.

Application materials should include a completed application form, letters of recommendation, a sample of philosophical writing, and transcripts of all previous college work. Applicants are expected to have a bachelor’s degree from an accredited institution. An undergraduate major in philosophy is preferred, but students with other majors may be admitted if their records indicate a capacity for advanced work in philosophy. The Graduate School requires a minimum undergraduate grade point average of 3.0 (on a 4.0 scale) for the last 60 hours of coursework.

Admission to the physical therapy PhD program is granted by the dean of the Graduate School upon recommendation of the Department of Food, Nutrition, Dietetics and Health. Admission to the doctoral program in physical therapy is based on a review of the following application materials: a graduate school application, a statement of objectives, a vitae, official transcripts from each college or university attended, three letters of reference, and TOEFL scores for non-native English speakers. In addition, students who have successfully completed either a master’s degree in physical therapy or a doctor of physical therapy degree with an overall graduate GPA of 3.0 or higher are eligible for admission. It is recommended that students take the Graduate Record Exam (GRE) and score at the 40th percentile or above. Applicants must be eligible for licensure to practice physical therapy in a state, territory, or commonwealth of the United States or the District of Columbia.

Transcripts from all previous institutions attended. A grade point average of at least 3.0 on a 4.0 scale on the last 60 hours of undergraduate coursework is normally required for admission. Three letters of recommendation are also required and should be requested through the on-line system. A one-page statement of your academic objectives is required. The GRE general and physics subject tests are not required, but encouraged for all applicants. All students for whom English is a second language must demonstrate English proficiency by providing scores from TOEFL, IELTS-academic, or Pearson Test of English (PTE).

To be admitted to the doctoral program, a student must normally hold a bachelor's degree in physics with a GPA of 3.0 or better from an accredited university. Students who meet most but not all of the requirements may be admitted on a provisional basis. An undergraduate degree in a closely related field such as chemistry, mathematics, or engineering may be acceptable, provided the student has taken a sufficient number of advanced undergraduate physics courses. Applicants must provide a transcript of all undergraduate and graduate coursework and three letters of recommendation. GRE General Test and GRE Subject Test (Physics) scores are optional.

A bachelor's degree in any music discipline from a regionally accredited institution with a minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale. Three letters of recommendation from individuals in a position to comment on the applicant's potential for success in a graduate program. A written statement of objectives. A curriculum vitae or resume. A portfolio containing two to three work samples demonstrating your ability in popular music. An interview with a program faculty member may be requested.

Students admitted to the M.S. degree program are expected to have a bachelor’s degree from an accredited university with an undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher. For students with a GPA less than 3.0, conditional admission can be considered. Students from a variety of undergraduate majors are eligible for admission. All applicants are evaluated individually. Admission is based on academic record, a personal statement and letters of recommendation. The GRE is not required for admission. Application materials include: personal statement, three letters of recommendation, official transcript and application fee.
Program name: Prevention Science and Community Health MS

Requirements:
Applicants for the Ph.D. in prevention science must meet the admission requirements of the Graduate School at Kansas State University and the admission requirements of the Prevention Science and Community Health PhD program. A complete application will include the following materials submitted through the K-State Graduate School Application system:

A statement of purpose: The statement should be two pages (double spaced) and address the applicant’s research interests and experiences, professional goals, and a description of how the applicant’s interests align with those of the Prevention Science faculty.
A curriculum vita or resume
Three letters of recommendation: Recommendations should be submitted by individuals who can speak to the applicant’s academic and/or research potential. The online application will ask for the names and email addresses of three recommenders who will then be sent a link to a form to complete.
One academic or professional writing sample: The writing sample should demonstrate the applicant’s ability to synthesize literature and develop a logical argument (e.g., term paper, honors or master’s thesis, or a professional report).
Transcripts from all previous institutions
Graduate School application
Application fee

International applicants must meet English proficiency requirements as established by the Graduate School.
GRE is not required for admission.
Program name: Prevention Science and Community Health PhD

Requirements:
A minimum GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale is required on the last 60 hours of undergraduate coursework for regular admission. Applicants not meeting the minimum GPA requirement may be considered for provisional admission if they can show evidence for potential success in the graduate program. A completed bachelor’s degree is required for admission. No specific undergraduate major is required.

All applicants must submit:
1. Transcripts from all previously attended universities
2. Three letters of reference
3. Resume or CV
4. Letter of intent describing their motivation to join the program and their career objectives.
Program name: Product Design MS (Cosmetics and Consumer Goods)

Requirements: Applicants for this program must have a bachelor of science degree in a STEM area, or a bachelor of arts degree in a STEM area from a liberal arts college with at least 15 credit hours in natural sciences. A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0 is required. Students also must provide a statement describing how this MS program would help them achieve their career goals, and one letter of recommendation. Students will be required to have completed at least one semester of an organic chemistry course and at least one semester of a biochemistry course prior to beginning the program. GRE scores are not required for admission into this program.

An undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher in the last 60 hours of coursework.
A portfolio of creative work.
A statement of intent describing the applicant’s interest in the program and goals for the master’s degree.
A curriculum vitae.
Three letters of recommendation.
For applicants whose native language is not English, a minimum TOEFL score of 79 (internet-based), with no section score lower than 20 on the reading, listening, and writing sections, is required.

Admission Criteria:

*   a bachelor’s degree from a regionally accredited institution,
*   a GPA of 3.0 on the last 60 hours of undergraduate coursework, and
*   prerequisite coursework in basic inferential statistics.

Required materials to be submitted within the online application:

*   Official transcripts from all previously attended colleges and universities. If you attended K-State, you do not need to provide K-State transcripts.
*   A Statement of Goals and Professional Experience (one to two pages, double-spaced) describing your previous educational and professional experience, your goals for this graduate program, and your long-term professional goals.
*   Three professional letters of recommendation from individuals who can speak to your professional and academic potential.
*   A current resume or vitae.

An earned master's degree in nursing (MSN) or a Doctor of Nursing Practice (DNP) from a CCNE or ACEN accredited nursing program. An unencumbered RN license in the state in which you plan to complete your clinicals. A minimum 3.0 GPA on a 4.0 scale. Completion of a graduate-level advanced pathophysiology, advanced pharmacology and advanced physical assessment course with a grade of B or better. Official transcripts from each institution attended. Three professional references. Resume or curriculum vitae. A personal statement of career goals and how this program will help them achieve those goals. Proof of English proficiency (if applicable).
Program name: Psychiatric Mental Health Nurse Practitioner Cert

Requirements:
The following materials are required to be submitted with the online application:

1. Graduate School application
2. Application fee
3. Transcripts: One official transcript is required for each college or university where you received your bachelor's degree(s) and for any post-baccalaureate coursework.
4. Letters of Recommendation: Three letters of recommendation are required from individuals who are familiar with your academic or professional abilities. You will enter the names and e-mail addresses of your recommenders into the online application system.
5. Statement of Purpose: This letter should describe your educational and career goals and how our graduate program will help you achieve those goals.
6. Resume or Curriculum Vitae (CV)

The following items are required as part of the application:
1. A personal statement that describes your background and experience, career goals, research interests and specific faculty members you are interested in working with. There is no specific word limit, but 2-3 pages double-spaced is typical.
2. A list of psychology courses taken as an undergraduate or graduate student, along with the grades received in each course.
3. A curriculum vitae (CV) that lists your education, research experience, publications and presentations, work experience, and honors and awards.
4. Three letters of recommendation.
5. Transcripts from all colleges and universities attended.

To apply for the Public Administration Graduate Certificate, you will need to submit the following: Graduate School application, Official transcripts, Statement of objectives: Provide a one- to two-page statement of your academic objectives, Three letters of recommendation, Resume, Application fee.

To be considered for admission, applicants must submit the following materials:

A 1-2 page statement of purpose describing your educational and career goals and why you believe the K-State MPA is a good fit for you.

A current resume.

A writing sample of no more than ten pages that illustrates your ability to research, analyze, and write.

Three letters of recommendation submitted directly from recommenders through the online application system.

Official transcripts from all previously attended colleges and universities. We require a 3.0 grade point average on a 4.0 scale in the last 60 hours of undergraduate coursework.

Scores from the Graduate Record Examination (GRE) are optional for all applicants. If you choose to submit GRE scores, please have them sent to Kansas State University by the Educational Testing Service. The K-State institutional code is 6334.

Applicants seeking admission to the M.P.A. program must hold a bachelor’s degree from an accredited college or university. They must meet the K-State Graduate School's admission requirements. Competitive applicants for regular admission will typically have a cumulative undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher. Applicants not meeting the 3.0 GPA minimum may be considered for provisional admission.

Admission to the Public Health certificate program is open to students currently enrolled in a graduate degree program at Kansas State University and to those with a completed bachelor’s degree from an accredited institution. Applicants must have a cumulative undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher. Applicants will be evaluated on prior academic performance (GPA), professional experience, and a statement of objectives.

Application materials required:

Statement of Objectives
Official transcripts from all post-secondary institutions attended
Three letters of reference from individuals who can speak to your academic potential

A bachelor's degree from an accredited institution. An undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher on a 4.0 scale. Three letters of recommendation from individuals who can speak to the applicant's academic and/or professional capabilities and potential. Statement of objectives (1-2 pages) that describes career goals and reasons for pursuing the MPH degree. Resume or curriculum vitae (CV). Official transcripts from each college or university attended. For non-native English speakers: an official TOEFL, IELTS or PTE score. The GRE is not required for admission into the MPH program.

Admission to the Master of Public Health program is granted to those with high promise for success. Such promise is evaluated on the basis of the following:

An undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher on a 4.0 scale.
Statement of objectives detailing the applicant's background, interest in public health, and how the degree will help the applicant in their career.
Three letters of reference from individuals who can assess the applicant's potential for graduate study.
A resume or curriculum vitae.
TOEFL scores for international students.
Graduate Record Examination (GRE) is not required.
A grade of B or better in a college algebra or a statistics course.
At least one year of relevant work experience is highly recommended but not required.

Students may apply for admission to the accelerated BS/MPH program at any time after they have completed a minimum of 60 undergraduate credit hours. A minimum GPA of 3.2 on all college or university courses is required. Application materials include: Application to the Graduate School, Statement of objectives (1-2 pages), Three letters of recommendation, Official transcripts from all post-secondary institutions, Resume or curriculum vitae.

Students applying for admission to the MSPH program are expected to have completed a baccalaureate degree with an overall GPA of 3.0 or higher. For students with degrees from a U.S. institution, official transcripts from all colleges/universities attended are required. For international students, a transcript evaluation by a credentialing agency is required.

In addition to the application form and fee, all applicants must submit a written statement describing their interest in the public health program and career goals. Applicants also need to provide a curriculum vitae or résumé and arrange for the submission of three letters of reference.

The MPH program at K-State has received a GRE waiver. We no longer require the GRE for admission to the program. All other admission requirements are still in place.

International students must also meet K-State’s general requirements for graduate admission. Information on these requirements is available from the Graduate School.

All applicants must submit the following materials:

Online graduate school application.
Graduate school application fee.
One official transcript from each college or university attended. GPA of 3.0 or higher in the last 60 hours of undergraduate coursework is required.
Statement of goals and career objectives (no more than 2 pages).
Resume or curriculum vitae (no more than 2 pages).
Three letters of reference.
For international students for whom English is not a first language, a TOEFL, IELTS, or PTE score is required.
The GRE is optional. However, if the applicant feels that their scores will enhance their application, they may be submitted.

Applicants should have an undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher. Applicants with a lower GPA may be admitted provisionally if they show promise in other areas. The GRE is not required for admission. Required application materials include: the Graduate School application form, transcripts from all colleges and universities attended, three letters of recommendation, a 1-2 page statement of purpose, and a resume or Curriculum Vitae (CV). English proficiency test scores are required if applicable.

To be admitted to the Master of Mass Communications program, students must have a bachelor’s degree from an accredited institution with a grade point average (GPA) of 3.0 or higher on a 4.0 scale in their junior and senior years.

International students whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency. Minimum scores for admission are 550 (paper-based), 213 (computer-based), or 79 (internet-based) on the TOEFL exam; 6.5 on the IELTS; or 58 on the Pearson Test of English (PTE).

Items to be included in your application:
1. A statement of objectives. Please provide a statement of objectives, double-spaced, of between 300-500 words describing your professional goals and how the master's degree in mass communication from Kansas State University will help you achieve those goals.
2. A curriculum vitae or resume.
3. A sample of your professional or academic writing.
4. Three letters of recommendation.
5. Official transcripts from each institution you have attended.
6. Graduate Record Exam (GRE) scores are optional. The institution code for Kansas State University is 6334.
